LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Kingdom of Thailand 
  
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector  (subsector):  Transport,  and  information  and 
communication technology (road transport) 
Themes  (subthemes):  Economic  growth  (widening  access  to 
markets  and  economic  opportunities),  private  sector 
development  (public  private  partnerships),  and  regional 
cooperation (other regional public goods)   
Location impact: Rural (medium), urban (low), national (high), and 
regional (medium) 
Partnership: World Bank  
  
Environment  Category  B  sensitive.  A  summary  initial  environmental 
Assessment  examination  was  prepared  and  circulated  to  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Board of Directors and made public 
through the ADB website on 19 February 2009. 
  
Project Description  The  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Highway  Expansion 
Project  will  upgrade  178  kilometers  (km)  of  two-lane  national 
highways to four-lane divided highway standard. Highway 12 from 
Phitsanulok  to  Lom  Sak  (105  km)  is  on  the  GMS  East–West 
Economic Corridor; and Highway 359 from Phanom Sarakham to 
Sa Kaeo (73 km) is along the GMS Southern Economic Corridor.  
 
The Project will also assist the Department of Highways (DOH) 
under  the  Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  in  preparing  an 
implementation plan for the Strategic Intercity Motorway Network. 
This will include a detailed and coordinated implementation and 
financing  plan  for  strategic  intercity  motorways  along  three 
corridors radiating out from Bangkok to a distance of 200–250 km, 
as well as a detailed analysis of financing alternatives.

ii       
Rationale  After  3  decades  of  rapid  economic  development,  Thailand’s 
growth has slowed. Strengthening competitiveness has become 
the  centerpiece  of  Thailand’s  economic  policy  to  reinvigorate 
growth. Deficient infrastructure is consistently cited as a major 
constraint on productivity growth. To address high logistics costs 
in  the  transport  sector,  the  DOH  is  prioritizing  five  areas:  (i) 
intercity motorways, (ii) Bangkok express ring roads, (iii) industrial 
ring  roads,  (iv)  four-lane  highway  widening,  and  (v)  roadway 
network  connections  to  neighboring  countries.  ADB’s  strategy 
focuses  on  assisting  the  MOT  in  these  five  areas  of  road 
development.  In  the  longer  term,  ADB  can  offer  the  most 
additionality  by  assisting  the  MOT  in  the  development  of  the 
motorway  network  using  public–private  partnerships.  However, 
planning  for  the  motorway  network  is  incomplete,  whereas 
preparation for making critical sections of the highway network 
four lanes—which is essential in the short to medium term—is well 
advanced. 
   
  The economic corridor approach, which was adopted by GMS 
leaders and reaffirmed by the 15th GMS Ministerial Conference 
(June 2009, Cha-am, Thailand), aims to (i) generate more cross-
border trade; (ii) extend the benefits of improved transport links to 
remote and landlocked locations in the GMS, which have been 
disadvantaged by their lack of integration with more prosperous 
and better-located neighboring areas; (iii) provide a spatial focus 
to GMS activities, with the backbone, growth centers, and nodal 
points serving as catalysts for the development of surrounding 
areas; (iv) open up many opportunities for investments from within 
and outside the GMS; and (v) enhance the impact of subregional 
activities through the clustering of projects. The adoption of this 
approach  assumes  that  the  underlying  national  networks  are 
adequate  and  efficient,  which  has  not  been  the  case  in  most 
countries. Cross-border traffic constitutes a small portion of total 
road traffic in Thailand, but ongoing improvements in transport 
infrastructure could soon exhaust the capacity of already busy 
roads. Therefore, managing road network capacity in the GMS 
corridors  is  required  to  avoid  defeating  the  purpose  of 
transforming these corridors into full-fledged economic corridors.

iii 
Impact and Outcome  The project impact will be an increase in competitiveness of the 
local economy in the provinces along the East–West Economic 
Corridor  (EWEC)  and  Southern  Economic  Corridor  (SEC).  By 
2018,  gross  domestic  product  in  the  provinces,  in  which  the 
project highways are expanded, is expected to be increased by 
20%, and value of cross-border trade carried by road transport 
with other GMS countries along the EWEC and SEC is expected 
to be increased by 20%, compared to the baseline data of 2010. 
The project outcome will be a more efficient and safer EWEC and 
SEC in Thailand. Compared to the baseline data, a reduction in 
passenger  and  freight  operating  costs  of  10%,  a  reduction  in 
travel times of 15%, an increase in traffic volume of 5%, and a 
reduction in traffic accidents fatalities of 40% are expected for the 
project highway sections by 2015.  
   
Project Investment Plan   The Project is estimated to cost $179.4 million, including taxes 
and duties of $15.4 million.  
   
Financing Plan  A loan of $77,100,000 from ADB's ordinary capital resources will 
be provided under ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility. The loan will have a 15-year term including 
a  grace  period  of  5  years,  an  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. 
  
Allocation and Relending  The loan from ADB will be provided to the Kingdom of Thailand. 
Terms  The proceeds of the loan will be directly disbursed to civil works 
contractors and consultants to be engaged by the DOH under the 
Project. 
  
Period of Utilization  30 June 2015 
  
Estimated Project  31 December 2014 
Completion Date 
  
Executing Agency  DOH 
   
Implementation  The  DOH  will  have  overall  responsibility  for  project 
Arrangements  implementation.  The  DOH  will  engage  and  direct  the  work  of 
consultants, and will procure and direct all contractors. Within the 
DOH, the deputy director general–engineering, who will be the 
project  director,  will  be  responsible  for  project  implementation. 
The director, Highway Construction Bureau, will assist the project 
director  as  the  deputy  project  director.  The  assistant  project 
director, who will be the director, Bureau of International Highways 
Cooperation, will have day-to-day responsibility.

iv       
Procurement  All procurement to be financed under the ADB loan will be carried 
out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time). All civil works to be funded from the 
ADB loan will be procured using international competitive bidding 
procedures with prequalification. Eight civil works packages will be 
procured, of which five will be for Highway 12 (Phitsanulok–Lom 
Sak) and three for Highway 359 (Phanom Sarakham–Sa Kaeo). 
   
Consulting Services  The  DOH  will  recruit  an  international  consulting  firm  for  the 
construction supervision consulting services using the quality- and 
cost-based  selection  procedures,  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). The quality and cost ratio is 80:20. The full technical 
proposal  will  be  used.  About  65  person-months  of  input  from 
international  experts  will  be  required  with  about  145  person-
months from national experts to assist the international experts. 
Expertise will be required in civil works contract management, 
highway  construction,  road  safety,  resettlement  and  social 
impacts, HIV/AIDS awareness, environmental impacts mitigation, 
and project performance monitoring. 
   
Project Benefits and  The major beneficiaries of the Project will be the residents of the 
Beneficiaries  project area and users of transport services within Thailand and in 
the GMS. By reducing travel times and vehicle operating costs 
along the improved sections, the Project will encourage economic 
activities  in  the  affected  provinces.  The  Project's  economic 
benefits are derived primarily from savings on vehicle operating 
costs and travel time. The estimated economic internal rate of 
return (EIRR) for the project road is 15.8%, indicating that the 
Project is economically viable. The results of sensitivity testing 
and risk analyses indicate that the Project is robust with a low risk 
of the EIRR falling below the minimum acceptable EIRR of 12%.

v 
Risks and Assumptions  The Project has been designed to reduce potential risks. A full 
resettlement  plan  has  been  prepared,  and  the  engineering 
designs  incorporate  measures  to  reduce  resettlement  impacts. 
Environmental documentation has been prepared in compliance 
with  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002).  Previous  road  sector 
projects in Thailand identified the following issues: (i) procurement 
was  delayed  because  the  DOH  was  not  familiar  with  ADB’s 
standard bidding documents; (ii) some covenants, especially on 
submission of audited accounts, were not complied with, and (iii) 
an  excessive  number  of  components  involving  too  many 
executing  agencies  complicated  project  administration.  To 
address  these  issues,  the  following  measures  have  been 
incorporated  in  the  design  of  the  Project:  (i)  the  project 
preparation  technical assistance (TA)  consultants  are  assisting 
DOH in preparing international standard contract documentation 
for  the  civil  works  following  the  requirements  of  ADB’s 
international competitive bidding procedures, and will assist DOH 
in undertaking the procurement until the contracts are awarded; 
(ii) timely compliance with loan covenants will be addressed in all 
ADB  loan  review  missions;  and  (iii)  the  Project  has  only  two 
components, and the DOH will be the Executing Agency for both. 
  
Technical Assistance  Technical assistance (TA) will be provided under the Project for 
the  preparation  of  the  implementation  plan  for  the  Strategic 
Intercity Motorway Network. The overall objective of the TA will be 
to provide the Government with a detailed implementation plan for 
the  three  motorway  corridors,  and  prepare  the  highest  priority 
project ready for award and implementation using an appropriate 
public–private  partnership  model.  The  cost  estimate  for  these 
services is $1.45 million; it is proposed that ADB will finance $1.0 
million. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Special  Fund.  The  Government  of  Thailand  will  finance  the 
remaining  $0.45  million  through  in-kind  contributions  of  the 
Executing Agency. The DOH will be the Executing Agency for the 
Project,  and  the  Bureau  of  Planning  under  the  DOH  will  the 
implementing agency responsible for day-to-day oversight.  
 
An  international  consulting  firm,  in  association  with  national 
consultants,  will  undertake  the  consulting  services  for  the  TA. 
ADB will hire the consultant using the quality- and cost-based 
selection procedures, according to the ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants.  The  quality  and  cost  ratio  is  90:10.  The 
simplified  technical  proposal  will  be  used.  About  45  person-
months  of  consulting  inputs  will  be  required  for  services 
implemented  over  18  months  (1  April  2010  to  30  September 
2011).

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Kingdom of Thailand for the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Highway Expansion 
Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for the implementation 
plan  for  the  Strategic  Intercity  Motorway  Network  Project,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the 
proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Over the past 3 decades, Thailand has become one of the most dynamic and diversified 
economies in Southeast Asia. Rapid economic growth in the past 20 years has significantly 
reduced poverty, particularly in northeastern Thailand. By 2007 the official national poverty 
headcount ratio was 8.1%. Thailand’s gross domestic product (GDP) expanded at an average 
annual rate of 6.2% from 2002 to 2004, but slowed down to 4.8% in 2007 and 2.6% in 2008. 
GDP is envisaged to contract by 2.0% from 2008 to 2009 because of the global economic 
recession. As many people have incomes that place them just above the poverty line, the recent 
economic recession could push them back into poverty. Strengthening competitiveness has 
become the centerpiece of Thailand’s economic policy agenda to reinvigorate economic growth. 
The 10th National Economic and Social Development Plan1 emphasizes that Thailand’s path to 
a more competitive, productive, and open economy will require more investment in economic 
capital, which the plan defines as having physical, financial, and human dimensions. This 
approach is consistent with priority initiatives to invest in physical and social infrastructure, to 
develop the domestic capital market, and to become a knowledge-based economy. Since the 
economy depends heavily on exports, which account for more than two-thirds of GDP, and in 
line with the 10th plan, economic growth should be stimulated by increasing trade within the 
GMS through investment in transport infrastructure of the GMS corridors in Thailand.  
 
3.  The economy’s performance over the medium term will depend on political stability, and 
on  raising  productivity  and  competitiveness  by  pushing  through  priority  infrastructure 
investments and advancing structural reforms. Transport infrastructure has been important in 
supporting Thailand’s growth and meeting the demand for transport services. The demand for 
infrastructure services and infrastructure investment has declined, and especially investment for 
roads and highways construction sharply decreased from 2006 to 2008. However, in the long 
run,  traffic  demand  will  grow  rapidly  and  road  capacity  shortages  will  emerge.  Transport 
bottlenecks will constrain economic growth, and the impact of insufficient investment in transport 
infrastructure is becoming increasingly evident. Deficient infrastructure is consistently cited as a 
major constraint on private investment and productivity growth.2 For example, logistics costs in 
Thailand are estimated to be as high as 20% of GDP, compared with 11% in Japan, 10% in the 
United States, and 7% in the European Union. Therefore, the Government has programmed 
large-scale  investments  in  the  road  subsector,  such  as  constructing  intercity  motorways, 
widening highways to four lanes, and strengthening roads connections with the neighboring 
countries  (para.11).  The  intercity  motorways  project  from  2007  to  2017  and  the  four-lane

4.  The  GMS  transport  network  in  Thailand  is  in  good  condition  relative  to  the  GMS 
transport network in other countries. With funding from ADB, Japan, and the World Bank, an 
initial rehabilitation program on the GMS East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC) has been 
completed in Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) and Viet Nam. A minimum standard 
of an all-weather sealed, two-lane highway has been achieved across the EWEC sections in 
Lao  PDR,  and  Viet  Nam.  Similarly  for  the  Southern  Economic  Corridor  (SEC),  an  initial 
rehabilitation program in Cambodia and Viet Nam is underway, and large sections have been 
completed with funding from ADB, Japan, the OPEC Fund for International Development, and 
the World Bank. With this minimum standard throughout both corridors about to be achieved, 
attention has turned to sections where improvements to a four-lane standard are required.  
 
5.  At the Third GMS Summit held in March 2008 in Vientiane, Lao PDR, a GMS Plan of 
Action, 2008–20123 was adopted. This plan includes a project to upgrade the EWEC within 
Thailand (Mae Sot–Mukdahan) and the GMS Highway Expansion Project. The Government of 
Thailand intends to improve the entire length of the sections of the EWEC and SEC that lie 
within Thailand. For the EWEC in Thailand, work is under way to upgrade a series of sections of 
highway, and planning has been completed for upgrading the remaining sections in phases. Of 
the remaining work, the first phase will upgrade 105 kilometers (km) from Phitsanulok to Lom 
Sak. Detailed engineering for these sections is in progress. The Department of Highways (DOH) 
will  upgrade  highways  along  the  remainder  of  the  EWEC  under  the  Mae  Sot–Mukdahan 
upgrading project, as included in the GMS Plan of Action. For the SEC between Bangkok and 
the border with Cambodia, the entire length has been upgraded to a four-lane highway with the 
exception of a 73 km section between Phanom Sarakham and Sa Kaeo. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
6.  The DOH has had sufficient funds to cover all routine maintenance, but not enough to 
cover periodic maintenance requirements on all arterial roads. The World Bank’s Highways 
Management Project4 helped to reduce this backlog by funding work on 700 km of national 
highways, and enhancing the planning and programming capability at the DOH. The DOH's 
road maintenance budget has risen significantly. The road maintenance budget as a percentage 
of the total DOH budget was 17.5% in 1995, 25.6% in 2000, and 28.1% in 2008. The gap in 
periodic maintenance funding for the arterial roads will be completely bridged within 4–5 years. 
 
7.  The economic corridor approach, which was adopted by GMS leaders and reaffirmed by 
the 15th GMS Ministerial Conference (June 2009, Cha-am, Thailand), aims to (i) generate more

prosperous and better-located neighboring areas; (iii) provide a spatial focus to GMS activities, 
with the backbone, growth centers, and nodal points serving as catalysts for the development of 
surrounding areas; (iv) open up many opportunities for investments from within and outside the 
GMS; and (v) enhance the impact of subregional activities through the clustering of projects. 
The adoption of this approach assumes that the underlying national networks are adequate and 
efficient, which has not been the case in most countries. Cross-border traffic constitutes a small

capacity in the GMS corridors is required to avoid defeating the purpose of transforming these

8.  The  governments  in  the  GMS  have  recognized  that  providing  subregional  physical 
infrastructure is a necessary but not sufficient condition for more connectivity among the six 
GMS countries. As part of the economic corridor approach, mitigating nonphysical barriers to 
the cross-border movement of goods and people is important to increase efficiency, reduce 
costs, and maximize the economic benefits of improved subregional transport infrastructure. To 
mitigate such barriers, the six GMS countries5 have negotiated, signed, and ratified a cross-
border transport agreement (CBTA). Formulated under a series of ADB TA projects, the CBTA 
provides a practical approach to streamline regulations and reduce nonphysical barriers to the 
cross-border transport of goods and people in the GMS. It incorporates the principles of bilateral 
or multilateral actions, and flexibility in recognizing differences in procedures in each of the GMS 
countries. The implementing guidelines of the CBTA have been signed and are expected to be  
ratified by all of the GMS countries in 2009. Implementation of the CBTA along major GMS 
corridors is expected to start in 2010. More information on the CBTA is in Appendix 2. 
 
9.  Private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  financing  in  Thailand  has  suffered  from 
financial and contractual problems, and private investors may not be ready to reenter the 
market. A better policy environment is needed for private sector participation in the provision 
and  management  of  infrastructure  services,  and  for  improvement  of  the  infrastructure 
prioritization and delivery process to allow good projects to be implemented in a timely and 
efficient manner. The World Bank-financed Highways Management Project (footnote 4) has a 
TA component that will (i) recommend revisions to Thailand's policy, legal, and regulatory 
framework for the roads sector to ensure a clear separation of responsibilities and to provide 
effective  management  of  road  infrastructure;  (ii)  develop  a  program  for  increasing  the 
institutional capacity of the DOH, which will be responsible for managing highway assets; and 
(iii) prepare a preliminary technical and financial assessment of the Bang Pa-In (Bangkok) to 
Nakhon Ratchasima motorway, including preparation of a concession agreement for a public–
private partnership to finance, implement, and operate the motorway. The TA component was 
completed in the second quarter of 2009. 
 
1.  The Government’s Strategy 
 
10.  To reduce logistics cost and increase the country’s global competitiveness, the Thai 
Cabinet on 27 February 2007 agreed upon a Thailand logistics road map. The overall objective 
of the road map is to reduce logistics costs in Thailand through the promotion of (i) more 
efficient logistics in the production sector, (ii) more efficiency in the transport sector, (iii) the

development of private sector logistics businesses, (iv) better facilitation for international trade, 
and (v) better human resource development.  
 
11.  To support the policy of the Cabinet with respect to increasing efficiency in the transport 
sector, the Ministry of Transport (MOT) and its Office of Transport and Traffic Policy, with the 
DOH, will prioritize five areas of road development: (i) intercity motorways, (ii) Bangkok express 
ring roads, (iii) industrial ring roads, (iv) widening of highways to four lanes, and (v) roadway 
network  connections  to  neighboring  countries.  Within  the  road  subsector,  the  Government 
intends to pursue its overall goal of reducing logistics costs and maintaining or increasing the 
country’s regional competitiveness primarily within the framework of these five areas. A number 
of challenges and constraints must be overcome to achieve this goal within a reasonable period, 
including  (i)  developing  a  broadly  based  financing  plan  that  reaches  well  beyond  the 
dependence on normal yearly DOH budget allocations; and (ii) making significant changes to 
Thailand's  legal  and  contractual  frameworks  to  provide  the  environment  essential  for  the 
introduction of innovative public–private partnerships. 
 
12.  In 2009, the Government announced two economic stimulus packages to revitalize the 
economy  and  help  low-income  people  in  particular.  The  second  package  focused  on 
infrastructure investment, and the highway four-lane expansion is one of the major projects in 
the package. However, the Government cannot fund such large investment programs and 
projects from domestic financial sources alone. The FY2009 budget provides for expenditures of 
B1.835 trillion plus a supplementary budget of B116.7 billion, while revenue is expected to be 
B1.425 trillion. This will result in a fiscal deficit of B526.7 billion in 2009. Thus, in addition to 
tapping domestic capital markets, the Government is seeking to diversify the sources of funds 
for these programs and projects. It has approached ADB, Japan, World Bank, and others as 
potential cofinanciers. 
 
13.  Thailand has been an active member of the GMS program since its inception in 1992. 
Thailand has financed components of priority subregional transport projects in its territory, 
participated in subregional projects in the other areas of GMS cooperation, and assisted in the 
implementation of priority subregional projects in other GMS countries. Thailand initiated the 
Ayeyawaddy–Chao Phraya–Mekong Economic Cooperation Strategy initiative to complement 
GMS cooperation by enhancing the competitiveness of member countries (Cambodia, Lao 
PDR, Myanmar, Thailand, and Viet Nam), thereby facilitating deeper economic integration of the 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations. 
 
2.  Lessons  
 
14.  The most recent ADB-funded project in the road subsector in Thailand was the Second 
Regional Roads (Sector) Project,6 which was approved in September 1995 and completed in 
September 2004. In the project completion report,7 the following issues were identified: (i) cash

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
19.  The EWEC links the southern part of Myanmar and the northern and northeastern parts 
of Thailand, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam. This corridor has undergone significant infrastructure 
improvements, particularly the upgrading of Highway 9 in Lao PDR and Viet Nam, and the 
bridge across the Mekong River between Mukdahan and Savannakhet, which opened to traffic 
in  January  2007.  Within  Thailand,  improvements  to  the  corridor  have  included  upgrading 
sections to a four-lane standard using domestic funding. It is the policy of the Government of 
Thailand to upgrade the entire length of the EWEC within Thailand to a four-lane standard. The 
EWEC connects at a number of points in Thailand to the country's main highway network and 
the GMS North–South and Northeastern Corridors, thus providing good access to Bangkok and 
the ports of Thailand. Improving the project section will increase access to international trade 
with Lao PDR and Viet Nam, and accelerate the economic development of the less-developed 
areas along the EWEC. Trade at the Mukdahan-Savannakhet border checkpoint was sluggish 
during the construction of the Second Mekong International Bridge funded by Japan (December 
2003 to December 2006). However, trade in both directions has expanded significantly recently. 
Between 2006 and 2008, the value of Thai exports expanded by nearly 90%, while Lao PDR 
exports surged by more than 350% as a result of larger copper shipments and the rise in the 
price of that commodity. Movement of people has also increased from under 300 persons per 
day in 2000 to about 500 persons per day in 2006 and 750 persons per day in 2007.13 However, 
the number of vehicles crossing the border—estimated at about 150 vehicles a day—is below 
potential and a small improvement from the 130 vehicles a day that crossed the border in 2000.

20.  The SEC's central sub-corridor links Bangkok with Cambodia and the southern areas of 
Viet Nam, including Ho Chi Minh City, by a 924 km road. It may be extended west from Bangkok 
to provide an additional link with Myanmar. The subproject section on this corridor, Phanom 
Sarakham–Sa Kaeo, is the only one in Thailand that is not already four lanes. An alternative 
route using highways 304 and 33 is four lanes, but the route using Highway 359 (Phanom 
Sarakham–Sa Kaeo section) is the most direct and is preferred for long-distance traffic. It is a 
new road with a very high standard of alignment, avoiding the urban centers of Kabin Buri and 
Sa Kaeo that are located on the alternative route. The main border crossing point between 
Thailand and Cambodia is east of Sa Kaeo at Aranyaprathet–Poipet. The SEC continues as 
Cambodian Highway 5 to Phnom Penh (with a branch via Highway 6 to the major tourist site of 
Angkor Wat near Siem Reap), then as Highway 1 to the  Bavet–Moc Bai border crossing into 
Viet Nam, and finally as Viet Nam Highway 22 to Ho Chi Minh City. Formal cross-border exports 
from Thailand to Cambodia rose from B1.26 billion in 1996 to B32.2 billion in 2007, an average 
increase of 42.8% per year.14 The Aranyaprathet border checkpoint accounted for about half of 
the cross-border exports from Thailand to Cambodia. Major exports from Thailand include 
motorcycles and parts, cement, engines, livestock feeds, petroleum, woven fabrics, textiles, and 
chemical  fertilizers,  with  the  largest  being  motorcycles  and  parts.  Cross-border  imports  of 
Thailand from Cambodia also rose from B1.0 billion in 1996 to B1.6 billion in 2007, an annual 
average growth rate of 20%; the Aranyaprathet border checkpoint accounted for two-thirds of 
the total. The major products imported by Thailand through the border gates include metal 
wastes, used clothes, corn feeds for livestock, soybean grain, ready-made clothes, and tapioca. 
The balance of trade has consistently been in favor of Thailand, whose exports were 20 times 
larger than its imports in 2007. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
21.  The project impact will be increase in competitiveness of the local economy in the 
provinces along the EWEC and SEC. By 2018, GDP in the provinces, in which the project 
highways are expanded, is expected to be increased by 20%, and value of cross-border trade 
carried by road transport with other GMS countries along the EWEC and SEC is expected to be 
increased by 20%, compared to the baseline data to be collected in 2010. The project outcome 
will be a more efficient and safer EWEC and SEC in Thailand. Compared to the baseline data, a 
reduction in passenger and freight operating costs of 10%, a reduction in travel times of 15%, 
an increase in traffic volume of 5%, and a reduction in traffic accidents fatalities of 40% are 
expected for the project highway sections by 2015.

B.  Outputs 
23.  The Project will upgrade about 178 km of two-lane national highway to a four-lane 
divided  highway  standard.  Works  include  new  bridges  and  widening  of  existing  bridges, 
reinforced  concrete  box  and  pipe  culvert  improvements,  new  asphaltic  concrete  pavement 
sections, and the strengthening and overlay of existing pavement sections. In addition, specific 
roadway safety improvements, such as provision for pedestrian overpasses, improved signage 
and pavement markings, and pavement widening at bus stops, will be incorporated into the 
improvements. The 178 km are along two sections of highway: Highway 12 from Phitsanulok to 
Lom Sak (105 km) is on the EWEC; and Highway 359 from Phanom Sarakham to Sa Kaeo (73 
km), is along the SEC. A summary of the proposed civil works under this component is in 
Appendix 5. The DOH will establish a project performance monitoring system (para. 40). 
 
24.  Over the past 10 years, attempts have been made to initiate the development of the 
motorway network. However, these foundered  because a detailed implementation strategy and 
a credible financing plan were lacking. TA will be provided to assist the MOT and DOH in 
preparing an implementation plan for the Strategic Intercity Motorway Network Project. The plan 
will develop a detailed and coordinated implementation and financing plan for strategic intercity 
motorways along three corridors radiating out from Bangkok to a distance of 200–250 km, and 
will include a detailed analysis of financing alternatives. This implementation plan is intended to 
provide the basis for future ADB assistance to Thailand’s road subsector through public and 
private sector operations. ADB will fund this component through a TA grant.

IV.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Background 
42.  The road network in Thailand comprises about 202,000 km, of which about 51,500 km 
are classified as highways, 150,000 km as rural roads, and about 450 km as controlled access 
expressway and motorways. The DOH is the primary Government agency responsible for the 
planning, construction, maintenance, and operation of the road network. Over the past 10 years, 
the Government's highway subsector strategy has focused on making national highways four 
lanes. However, during this period, intercity motorways or additional expressways in the vicinity 
of Bangkok have not been emphasized, and a coherent public investment plan for intercity 
motorways does not appear to exist. The development of this network is becoming essential if 
adequate highway capacity is to be provided, particular in the areas close to Bangkok. The 
Government prioritizes construction of intercity motorways (para. 11). The World Bank-financed 
Highways Management Project (footnote 4) includes a TA component prepared for the DOH 
that will provide recommendations for implementing a restructured framework for private sector 
participation in financing, construction, operations, and maintenance activities.  
 
43.  The GMS economic corridors are defined as an expansion of key transport corridors to 
enhance economic activities and benefits. The development of nodal points of the corridors, 
which should serve as centers for enterprise development, is required to transform transport 
corridors into economic corridors. Bangkok is one of the principal nodal cities in the GMS, and is 
the origin and destination of the GMS North–South, Southern, and Southern Coastal Corridors. 
Construction of the motorways in the Bangkok metropolitan area will strengthen connectivity 
between Bangkok and cities in the suburbs of Bangkok, and will induce private investment in the 
metropolitan area. In the GMS context, the Bangkok motorway projects will serve as the nodal 
development,  compared  to  the  GMS  Highway  Expansion  Project  and  other  GMS  highway 
projects referred as link development.     
 
B.  Proposed Study 
44.  The overall objective of the TA study will be to provide the Government with a detailed 
implementation plan for the motorway corridors, and to prepare the highest priority project ready 
for award and implementation using an appropriate public–private partnership model. The TA 
will concentrate on three motorway links: (i) Chonburi to Map Ta Put, including an access link to 
Laem Chabang Port; (ii) Bang Yai to Nakhon Pathom (Bang Pong) to Cha-am; and (iii) Nakhon 
Pathom to Kanchanaburi. In general, the TA study will build upon the work and documentation

15 
already prepared under the World Bank's TA for the DOH on the Bang Pa-In to Nakhon 
Ratchasima Motorway. To realize the overall objective, the TA study will carried out in three 
phases:  (i)  the  inspection  and  screening  phase  to  review  and  study  market  issues  and 
regulatory structures for the Thai road sector; (ii) the project preparation phase to prepare a 
project for the selected motorway link; and (iii) the procurement assistance phase to finalize the 
tender documents and assist the DOH with procurement. A summary of the TA, including terms 
of reference for the consulting services, reporting requirements, and detailed breakdown of the 
cost estimate, is in Appendix 11. 
 
45.  These services are estimated to cost $1.45 million; it is proposed that ADB will finance 
$1.0 million. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by Japan Special Fund. The Government 
of  Thailand  will  finance  the  remaining  $0.45  million  through  in-kind  contributions  of  the 
Executing Agency—remuneration and allowances for counterpart staff; furnished offices for the

46.  The DOH will be the Executing Agency for the study. The Bureau of Planning will be the

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
48.  Economic Viability. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project was 
calculated by comparing the with- and without-project scenarios for the project highways. In the 
without-project scenario, the highways are assumed to remain at their current width. Both 
project scenarios include routine and periodic maintenance according to current Thai standards. 
Without the Project, the traffic volume would exceed the capacity of the highways, which would 
become congested—leading to increases in travel time and vehicle operating costs (VOCs). 
With the Project, travel time would decrease because of higher speeds, and VOCs would 
decline  because  of  the  faster  and  smoother  ride  on  the  project  highways.  The  economic 
analysis was carried out using the Highway Design and Maintenance Standards Model. The 
model evaluates the project investment considering capital and recurrent costs, as well as the

16   
benefits derived from savings in road user costs for the with- and without-project cases. In the 
economic analysis, the project life after completion of works was taken to be 20 years. The 
economic costs of the Project include the resource costs for construction, and operation and 
maintenance; and the social costs of compensation for land acquisition and resettlement. The 
economic benefits were quantified in terms of VOC, time, and accident cost savings. The 
estimated EIRR for the Highway 12 section is 12.2% and for the Highway 359 section is 20.1%, 
indicating that all project components are economically viable. The estimated EIRR for the 
Project  as  a  whole  is  15.8%.  The  economic  viability  is  generally  robust.  The  capital  cost 
increase up to 52.6% or the benefit reduction up to 36.1% ensures the project EIRR higher than 
12%. A risk analysis using the @Risk computer program was also undertaken to determine the 
probability of the EIRR falling below 12%. The analysis shows a 15.3% risk that the Project 
would not reach the minimum EIRR of 12% for economic viability. The economic analysis is 
summarized in Appendix 12. 
 
49.  Resettlement.  The  highway  right-of-ways  (ROWs)  has  been  acquired,  and  it  was 
established and demarcated as early as the 1950s (Highway 12) and 2000 (Highway 359). The 
entire ROW of highways 12 and 359 will be cleared of all obstructions. The census and detailed 
measurement surveys carried out in October and November 2008 in Highway 359 identified 
about 261 households. An additional 92 households were found during the census and detailed 
measurement  survey  in  March  2009  in  Highway  12.  These  households  had  stalls  and/or 
shelters and tilling paddy land inside the ROW. The resettlement plan prepared for the Project 
was formulated in a way that recognizes that, while the ROWs of the two highways have been 
acquired, the affected people’s livelihood will be able to continue with minimal disruption and 
that their socioeconomic conditions will be maintained, if not improved. A copy of the project 
resettlement plan is in Supplementary Appendix A and a summary of the resettlement plan is in 
Appendix 13. The DOH will assist by coordinating with the resettlement coordinating committee 
and Tambon Administration Office to find replacement land for stalls and shelters in a way that 
will allow for the gradual transfer of business operation to the new site, thereby avoiding any 
business disruption. Poor and vulnerable households will be given priority in choosing stalls in 
the new sites. Consultation meetings were carried out during preparation of the resettlement 
plan,  and  key  information  was  disclosed  to  the  affected  people  before  ADB  appraisal. 
Implementation arrangements have been designed following a participatory approach, while a 
grievance mechanism and monitoring have been established to ensure compliance with the 
resettlement plan from updating to implementation.  
 
50.  Environmental Impacts. The Project will widen two sections of paved highways. Based 
on the requirements of the ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), the Project has been classified as 
environmental  category  B  (sensitive)  because  the  alignment  along  Highway  12  (the 
Phitsanulok–Lom Sak section) traverses the Thung Salaeng Luang National Park and several 
sensitive watershed designations. The highway was constructed in 1960, while the national park 
was declared as such in 1975. The proposed highway expansion will be restricted to areas 
within the existing 60-meter ROW of Highway 12. The park designation does not extend inside 
the ROW pursuant to the Royal Decree for Separation of Highway Right-of-Way from Thung 
Salaeng  Luang  National  Park.  Further,  all  portions  of  the  ROW  that  encompass  sensitive 
watersheds or are adjacent to the national park have been previously disturbed or developed 
through activities such as logging, agriculture, or roadway and commercial construction. As 
such,  these  areas  are  in  a  degraded  condition  with  respect  to  ecological  resources.  The 
adjacent portions of the national park have also been previously degraded through similar 
activities, as noted for the ROW. Native habitats generally are absent within 50–60 meters of 
the ROW, and the most sensitive (core) habitat areas of the park are about 2 km or more south 
of the alignment. No protected areas, such as national parks, designated forests, or sensitive

17 
watersheds, are within or adjacent to Highway 359 (the Phanom Sarakham–Sa Kaeo section). 
The section is in an area of generally level terrain and is predominantly agricultural. 
 
51.  The predicted environmental impacts during construction include air pollution, mainly 
from dust emissions; noise and vibration; water pollution from fuel spills and improper waste 
disposal; soil erosion and siltation of water courses because of earthworks and extraction of 
borrow materials; and habitat loss from vegetation clearing. The Project is expected to improve 
the ecological condition within the ROW of the two highway sections. The Project will include 
extensive  tree  replanting  (utilizing  native  species),  landscaping,  erosion  control,  slope 
stabilization, and water quality control. Wildlife crossings will also be provided for road sections 
along Highway 12. These will be either project design or mitigation measures, and will include 
applicable  monitoring  programs  to  ensure  proper  function  and  identify  necessary  remedial 
measures. Impacts during the operations phase are expected to be limited mainly to air and 
noise pollution from vehicles. The proposed project design includes a number of monitoring 
efforts to identify site-specific locations where regulatory standards cannot be met. In those 
cases, additional mitigation measures will be implemented, as appropriate. 
 
52.  An EMP has been prepared detailing mitigation and monitoring requirements, associated 
implementation responsibilities, schedules, preliminary costs, reporting frequency, and capacity 
building or training requirements. Timely and proper implementation of mitigation measures 
defined in the EMP will help ensure that the Project will not significantly harm the environment. 
A copy of the summary initial environmental examination is in Supplementary Appendix B.  
 
53.  Gender. In the project area, poor women and households headed by females are more 
at risk economically (loss of productive assets because of construction activities) and socially 
(risks posed by HIV/AIDS, road safety, and possible human trafficking) than males. To address 
the  loss  of  livelihoods  of  poor  women  and  households  headed  by  females,  the  project 
resettlement plan includes livelihood restoration targeted at women in the project districts. A 
project-specific gender strategy has been prepared, as set out in the summary poverty reduction 
and social strategy (Appendix 4). The gender strategy includes capacity building training and 
consultation workshop with affected households to increase their understanding of resettlement 
issues (such as compensation, entitlements, and grievance procedures), and to develop skills 
for appropriate livelihood activities. The contractors and construction supervision consultant are 
also encouraged to employ preferentially female workers from project-affected households for 
their office work positions. 
 
54.  HIV. To meet the challenge of an increase in sexually transmitted infections, including 
HIV, that can be directly linked to construction-based activities, mitigation measures have been 
included. As part of an HIV awareness campaign, activities will include the distribution of free 
condoms to targeted groups, advice on access to testing and treatment for HIV and other 
sexually transmitted diseases, and greater awareness of behavior that increases risks. Activities 
under this campaign will be consistent with the work proposed under the TA for HIV Prevention 
and Infrastructure: Mitigating Risk in the Greater Mekong Subregion, funded by the Government 
of Australia.16 Awareness activities, including capacity building of the DOH, will also address 
human trafficking, awareness on safe migration, and community monitoring. The Project will 
support campaigns in schools and temples of local communities to raise awareness of the 
negative impacts of people trafficking. Consultations with a range of local experts (including law 
enforcement  officials)  strongly  suggested  that  there  is  little  causal  relationship  between

55.  Road Safety.  The four-lane highways are expected to provide road users with a safer 
environment compared with two-lane roads. However, to realize this benefit, road users who are 
accustomed to driving at low speeds on two-lane roads will have to adapt their behavior to the 
improved four-lane highways. To address the adaptation process and other road safety issues, 
road safety audits and road safety awareness campaigns are included in the tasks for the 
construction supervision consultant. 
 
56.  Project  Implementation.    Previous  road  sector  projects  in  Thailand  identified  the 
following issues: (i) procurement was delayed because the DOH was not familiar with ADB’s 
standard  bidding  documents;  (ii)  some  covenants,  especially  on  submission  of  audited 
accounts, were not complied with; and (iii) an excessive number of components involving too 
many executing agencies complicated project administration. To address these issues, the 
following  measures  have  been  incorporated  in  the  design  of  the  Project:  (i)  the  project 
preparation  TA  consultants  are  assisting  DOH  in  preparing  international  standard  contract 
documentation for the civil works following the requirements of ADB’s international competitive 
bidding procedures, and will assist DOH in undertaking the procurement until the contracts are 
awarded; (ii) timely compliance with loan covenants will be addressed in all ADB loan review 
missions; and (iii) the Project has only two components, and the DOH will be the Executing 
Agency for both.

A.  Introduction 
1.  The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) comprises Cambodia, Yunnan Province and 
Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region of the People’s Republic of China (PRC), Lao People's 
Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR),  Myanmar,  Thailand,  and  Viet  Nam.  In  1992,  with  the 
assistance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the six countries entered into a program of 
subregional  economic  cooperation.  The  ultimate  objective  of  the  program  is  to  facilitate 
sustainable  economic  growth  and  to  improve  the  standard  of  living  of  the  people  in  the 
subregion. The program has contributed to the development of infrastructure to enable the 
development and sharing of the resource base, and to promote a freer flow of goods and people 
in  the  subregion.  ADB’s  regional  cooperation  strategy  and  program  update  for  the  GMS1 
includes  four  strategic  pillars,  the  first  of  which  addresses  strengthening  connectivity  and 
facilitating cross-border movement and tourism. The high priority given to cooperation in the 
transport sector is because of the poor state of the transport infrastructure in most of the GMS, 
which is a major constraint to economic growth, trade, and other forms of cooperation. Most 
freight and passengers moved through the GMS by road. Although subregional traffic is still 
modest relative to domestic traffic, the governments of the GMS countries give high priority to 
the development of transport infrastructure links that will facilitate regional and international 
trade  and  economic  cooperation,  especially  when  such  transport  facilities  also  serve  their 
respective domestic needs.  
 
2.  The  main  thrusts  of  regional  cooperation  in  the  transport  sector  have  been: 
(i) developing the north–south corridor from Kunming in Yunnan Province of the PRC to Ho Chi 
Minh City in the southern part of Viet Nam, and the east–west corridor from Thailand and the 
central coast of Viet Nam through Lao PDR; (ii) linking the capitals, other population centers, 
and major tourist destinations in the subregion; (iii) helping develop remote and low-income 
areas traversed by subregional road projects by improving access to markets, and social and 
economic services; (iv) providing access to the sea for landlocked Lao PDR, and alternative 
access  to  seaports  for  such  areas  as  northeastern  Thailand  and  Yunnan  Province;  and 
(v) reducing, with the objective of eliminating, nonphysical barriers (such as regulations covering 
border crossings) to the movement of people and goods in the subregion.  
 
3.  To help accelerate subregional economic cooperation the GMS countries adopted the 
economic corridor approach to subregional development during the Eighth GMS Ministerial 
Meeting  held  in  Manila,  Philippines  in  1998.  Three  priority  GMS  economic  corridors  were 
identified during that meeting: the East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC), the North–South 
Economic Corridor, and the Southern Economic Corridor (SEC). The development of these 
corridors was subsequently designated as flagship initiatives under the Ten-Year GMS Strategic 
Framework, which leaders of the GMS countries endorsed during the First GMS Summit held in 
Phnom Penh, Cambodia in 2002. At the Third GMS Summit held in Vientiane, Lao PDR in 
March 2008, the GMS leaders stressed the need to redouble efforts to transform transport 
corridors into economic corridors to maximize benefits from improved physical connectivity in 
the subregion. GMS ministers reaffirmed this at their 15th meeting held in Cha-am, Thailand in 
June 2009.

B.  Greater Mekong Subregion Transport Sector Strategy 
4.  The GMS transport sector strategy provides a framework that is implemented through 
individual national strategies that often also involve subregional plans and agencies. Thus, each 
GMS member country has its own transport program developed for 5-year plans and as a basis 
for year-to-year budgets. These programs are supported to varying degrees with sector policy 
statements,  strategies,  objectives,  priorities, and  individual  project analyses.  The  programs 
incorporate consideration of the importance of undertaking GMS-related projects. While many 
regional and subregional cooperation groupings are involved in transport in the GMS, the GMS 
framework  allows  initiatives  to  be  endorsed at  the  highest  levels  of  leadership.  The  GMS 
concept has rapidly become an effective forum for international cooperation—from the working 
level to the heads of government level. This has provided the GMS with a leading role in 
coordinating projects and in developing strategy.  
 
5.  The GMS transport sector strategy study2 financed by ADB identified five key goals for 
transport: (i) to exploit synergies in the GMS transport system; (ii) to move towards an open 
market for transport services; (iii) to facilitate economic efficiency to reduce transport costs; 
(iv) to complete the GMS network and improve links with South Asia; and (v) to encourage 
multiple modes of transport. The GMS Highway Expansion Project will support these objectives 
by upgrading two sections of the Thai road system in two of the GMS corridors; EWEC and 
SEC.  
 
6.  The GMS transport corridors include strategic roads in the national road networks, and 
interconnections between these national transport networks. Generating trade and efficiency 
benefits from these corridors requires that the underlying national networks are adequate and 
efficient. This has not been the case in most GMS countries. ADB has funded GMS transport 
sector projects in four of the six member countries, as listed in Appendix 3, but has made no 
contribution  in  Thailand  or  in  Myanmar.  In  terms  of  investment  in  road  infrastructure,  the 
emphasis has been on the completion of “missing links” in the corridors. Roads in Thailand have 
not  been  a  high  priority  because  of  their  generally  good  design  standard  and  condition 
compared with the other countries. Within Thailand, GMS corridor routes are developed as part 
of a wider program of road upgrading using domestic funding. Traffic on some sections of the 
GMS economic corridors in Thailand is increasing to levels where upgrading of these roads is 
now required to prevent congestion. The combined impact of growing domestic traffic demand 
in Thailand and increasing cross-border traffic demand in step with rehabilitation and upgrading 
of the transport networks in the neighboring countries could soon exhaust the capacity of roads 
and highways in Thailand. Therefore, road network capacity in the GMS corridors must be 
managed to avoid defeating the purpose of developing these corridors.

14.  Conceptually,  GMS  economic  corridor  development  involves  a  holistic,  multisector 
approach,  where  infrastructure  development  is  linked  with  trade,  investment,  and  other 
economic, social, and environmental opportunities. The development of economic corridors8 is 
expected  to  help  in  achieving  the  vision  of  the  GMS  as  a  prosperous,  harmonious,  and 
integrated  subregion  through  more  connectivity,  enhanced  competitiveness,  and  a  greater 
sense of community. It supports the strategic thrusts of the GMS 10-Year Strategic Framework: 
(i) strengthening infrastructure links; (ii) facilitating cross-border trade, investment, and tourism; 
(iii) enhancing private sector participation and competitiveness; (iv) protecting the environment 
and  promoting  sustainable  use  of  shared  natural  resources;  and  (v)  developing  human 
resources and skills competencies. From a broader perspective, the development of the GMS 
economic corridors offers a means for the less-developed member countries of ASEAN to catch 
up  with  the  more  economically  advanced  member  countries,  and  to  reinforce  the  market 
integration process that is increasing in East Asia. 
 
15.  Operationally,  the  economic  corridor  approach  aims  to  (i)  extend  the  benefits  of 
improved transport links to remote and landlocked locations in the GMS, which have been 
disadvantaged by their lack of integration with more prosperous and better-located neighboring 
areas; (ii) provide a spatial focus to GMS activities, with the backbone, growth centers, and 
nodal points serving as catalysts for the development of surrounding areas; (iii) open up many 
opportunities for investments from within and outside the GMS; (iv) enhance the impact of 
subregional activities through the clustering of projects; (v) serve as a mechanism for prioritizing 
and  coordinating  investments  among  neighboring  countries;  and  (vi)  generate  tangible 
demonstration effects. 
 
E.  Impact of Greater Mekong Subregion Strategy on Traffic Growth 
 
16.  On most roads, cross-border traffic is a fraction of domestic traffic, but its share of total 
traffic is increasing. Passenger traffic has grown as a result of increased domestic demand and 
tourism, while commodity trade between the GMS countries has grown more quickly than trade 
in general. In 1992, about 5.7% of total GMS country trade was between GMS countries; by 
2003, it had risen to 12.0%, a period in which total trade grew rapidly. Within the GMS transport 
sector strategy study, a preliminary version of the GMS transport model (GTM) was developed 
to estimate traffic flows in the subregion to 2015. The analysis was based on both demand-side 
factors and supply-side issues. Demand-side factors included forecasts of key economic and 
demographic factors: (i) gross domestic product (GDP), (ii) population, (iii) GDP per capita, (iv) 
exports, (v) imports, and (vi) tourist arrivals. Supply-side issues included infrastructure and 
policy. Therefore, the GTM enabled the assessment of the impact of changes in, for example, 
road condition or faster border procedures. The GTM needs further work before it is accurate 
enough to analyze specific subprojects, but the traffic flow projections indicate that the GMS 
strategy will lead to higher traffic levels on many routes.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.    Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
The Project is not directly linked to Thailand’s national poverty reduction strategy, but rather to Thailand’s desire to deepen 
partnerships with its neighbors. It reflects a strong appreciation that inclusive and sustainable development in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS) brings growth and stability to Thailand. Similarly, if Thailand’s economy is strong, this will 
contribute to growth, development, and poverty reduction in neighboring countries. As a middle-income country, Thailand is 
also expected to assume a leadership role in maintaining and providing regional public goods, and in addressing cross-border 
issues such as environmental management, the trafficking of drugs and people, and the control of communicable diseases. In 
line  with  the  Millennium  Development  Goal  8  (Global  Partnerships),  these  economic,  social,  and  environmental 
interdependencies highlight the importance of strengthening Thailand’s role, capacity, and effectiveness as a development 
partner. 
 
Thailand plays a crucial role in realizing the four major areas of the GMS regional cooperation strategy and program by (i) 
strengthening connectivity and facilitating cross-border movement and tourism; (ii) integrating national markets to promote 
economic efficiency and private sector development; (iii) addressing health and other social, economic, and capacity building 
issues associated with subregional links; and (iv) managing the environment and shared natural resources, especially 
watershed systems of the Mekong River.

1.  Key Issues  
The  gross  provincial  product  (GPP)  of  the  project  provinces  reflects  the  fundamentally  different  levels  of  economic

Khon Kaen (the major center for economic development on the East–West Economic Corridor), Phitsanulok, and along the

The Project has not been designed specifically reduce poverty. Thailand is the least poor of the GMS countries with an official

socially and economically than elsewhere in the GMS, although levels of inequality are greater than in neighboring Lao PDR, 
Viet Nam, and southwestern People's Republic of China (PRC). 
 
The economic rationale underlying the widening of these GMS corridor highways to four lanes is that they will reduce the cost 
of delays for passenger and freight traffic. The lower costs for freight traffic will reduce the costs for goods consumed in the

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
The social and poverty analysis was conducted to assess the social and poverty impacts of this Project on people living in the 
provinces in northern and eastern Thailand where the two highways traverse. The economy in the project area depends 
mainly on agriculture and natural resources. The project area does not have any legal commercial forestry, as the forests of 
were almost completely logged out long ago. Access to forests to collect non-timber forest products is circumscribed, although 
permitted in some instances. Shrimp and prawn farming are relatively important in Chachoengsao because of its proximity to 
the Gulf of Thailand, but not in other provinces. Areas that have access to year-round sources of water have some small-
scale aquaculture, but such areas are few. Livestock-rearing is important in the project area. Elsewhere, project area shows 
little evidence of contract farming, except perhaps among vegetable growers such as the Hmong, who provide a range of 
cool-weather  vegetables  (e.g.,  peas,  beans,  and  broccoli)  to  high-end  supermarkets  in  Thailand.  However,  with  the 
establishment of biofuel factories to extract the juice of sugarcane for use in vehicles, some form of contract-based sugarcane 
farming is likely, because these factories require a guaranteed supply of harvested sugarcane. Apart from the manufacture of 
pulp and paper products and biofuels, the project area has little real manufacturing. However, there are many examples and 
small amounts of products being manufactured locally. Service industries are well developed in the major provincial centers, 
although Khon Kaen is the most developed in terms of education and health care. Other sectors, such as tourism, are not 
very well developed in the project area, except in Phetchabun. Better roads in the project area will facilitate travel to popular 
tourist destinations, and it is assumed that local business will benefit as well because of increased traffic. In general, the 
project area offers fewer jobs outside agriculture than in other more economically diversified provinces of Thailand. School 
completion rates are typically lower in the project area than elsewhere in Thailand. Thus, the project area has fewer formally 
well-educated people than in the main centers of Thailand’s economic development.   
 
Although the Project is not explicitly linked to poverty reduction issues, it does have some positive impacts relating to poverty 
reduction, including (i) agriculture-based income-generation activities (e.g., the ability to meet unmet demand for pork, beef, 
and chicken products in other GMS countries, especially the PRC; and importing sugarcane and cassava from the Lao PDR 
for value-adding into bio-fuels), resulting in the generation of more jobs, and widening highways to four lanes also makes it 
easier for poor farmers to transport crops such as sugarcane and cassava to biofuel processing plants in northeastern 
Thailand; and (ii) anticipated growth in domestic, regional, and international tourism, especially enabling regional tourists from 
other GMS countries to visit this part of Thailand rather than flying directly into the major tourist areas in Thailand such as 
Bangkok, Chiang Mai, and Chiang Rai, and for poorer people the existing forms of agro-tourism (including farm stays) 
increase  the  possibilities  for  non-farm-based  livelihood  opportunities.  Other  positive  impacts  include  the  (i)  greater 
development of small and medium-sized enterprises, especially with the bridging finance afforded when activities can be 
linked to Thailand’s One-Tambon (subdistricts), One-Product program; (ii) revitalization of local culture and preservation of 
traditional skills, including dance, music, embroidery, and silk-weaving; and, (iii) promotion of greater regional cultural 
understanding in a region where it has taken more than 4 decades to transcend lingering cultural doubts about GMS 
neighbors. 
 
The main social and livelihood impacts of the Project are related to temporary loss of stallholders’ incomes, increase in 
sexually  transmitted  infections  including  HIV/AIDS,  possible  increase  in  people  trafficking,  possible  increase  in  drug 
trafficking, depletion of common property resources, and an increased risk of road accidents.  
 
Negative resettlement impacts have been mitigated in the resettlement plan prepared for the Project. To meet the challenge 
of an increase in sexually transmitted infections including HIV/AIDS that can be directly linked to construction-based activities, 
a number of mitigation measures have been included. The HIV awareness campaign will include the distribution of free 
condoms to targeted groups, advice on access to testing and treatment for HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases, and 
increasing awareness of behavior that increases risks. Awareness activities will also address human trafficking, including 
capacity building of the Executing Agency, awareness on safe migration, and community monitoring. In the schools and 
temples of local communities, the Project will support measures to reinforce awareness of the negative impacts of people 
trafficking. Consultations with a range of local experts (including law enforcement officials) strongly suggested that there is 
little causal relationship between making these highways four lanes and an increase in people trafficking or drug trafficking. A 
road safety awareness program will address risks of increased traffic accidents. The environment management plan includes 
measures to address dust- and pollution-related issues.

SUMMARY OF PROPOSED CIVIL WORKS 
 
A.  Civil Works Scope 
 
1.  The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Highway Expansion Project involves upgrading 
about  178  kilometers  (km)  of  two-lane  national  highways  to  a  four-lane  divided  highway 
standard. Works include new bridges and widening of existing bridges, reinforced concrete box 
and  pipe  culvert  improvements,  new  asphaltic  concrete  pavement  sections,  and  the 
strengthening  and  overlay  of  existing  pavement  sections.  In  addition,  roadway  safety 
improvements, such as provision for pedestrian overpasses, improved signage and pavement 
markings, and pavement widening at bus stops, will be incorporated into the improvements. The 
178 km are along two sections of highways: (i) Phitsanulok–Lom Sak (105 km) is on the GMS 
East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC); and (ii) Phanom Sarakham–Sa Kaeo (73 km) is along 
the GMS Southern Economic Corridor (SEC). 
 
B.  Highway 12 from Phitsanulok to Lom Sak 
 
2.  The east–west alignment of the Phitsanulok–Lom Sak section (Highway 12) connects 
two of the primary north–south corridors (Highways 11 and 21) in central-northern Thailand. It is 
the  primary  road  connecting  two  of  the  richest  provinces  of  the  region,  Phitsanulok  and 
Phetchabun. The western end of the Phitsanulok–Lom Sak section starts in the Nan river valley 
near Wong Thong district, at an elevation of 50 meters and climbs more than 700 meters as it 
crosses through a series of small mountain passes.1 It passes through Nakhon Thai and Khao 
Kho districts, and then descends about 600 meters until it reaches the expansive Issan Plateau 
near an elevation of 160 meters in Lom Sak district.   
 
3.  The horizontal and vertical alignments in the mountainous terrain are often severe, 
requiring significant reductions in design speed. Many of these sections will necessitate large 
volumes of civil works earthwork quantities to complete improvements to a four-lane standard. 
The  existing  two-lane  road  is  centered  within  the  60-meter  right-of-way  (ROW),  and 
consequently  little  of  the  existing  roadway  section  or  bridges  can  be  salvaged  during  the 
widening work.2 The roadway section will be upgraded within the limit of existing ROW to the 
Department of Highways (DOH) four-lane divided class standard, i.e., traffic lanes 3.5–4.0 
meters wide, outer paved shoulders 2.0–2.5 meters wide, and inner paved shoulders 1.5–2.0 
meters wide. Construction will be divided into five contract packages. The primary civil works 
comprise  widening  of  embankments  and  cut  sections  to  accommodate  the  new  four-lane 
highway;  construction  of  sub-base  and  base  courses,  and  asphaltic  concrete  pavements; 
replacing  and  lengthening  of  existing  cross  drainage  structures.  The  works  also  include  a 
significant amount of erosion control and slope stabilization works (utilizing various geo-grid and 
reinforced earth slope protection techniques). The median width will vary greatly because of the 
roughness of the terrain, and the necessity to keep all limits of construction within the existing 
ROW. Medians sections include a 9-meter depressed median in open, flat areas; a 5.1-meter 
raised median with street lighting in more built-up areas; and a 3.8-meter wide median with 
concrete barrier. Six at-grade road intersections will be improved with channelization suitable for 
the new four-lane highway.

roads is expected to begin at different times and with different implementation periods. The

followed by a benefit period of 20 years. All benefits and costs are in constant early 2008 prices.

D.  Benefits 
6.  The benefits to road users is estimated as the differences between VOC, time cost for 
passengers, and accident costs in the with-project and the without-project cases using the 
HDM-4 model. The main benefit resulting from the improved road standard is in the form of 
travel time savings, which is a direct result of the higher speeds that are achieved on four-lane 
roads. VOC savings are smaller because the road surface condition of the present roads is 
already good to fair, and because higher speeds do not always produce VOC benefits because 
of progressively increasing fuel cost. Accident savings can only be estimated, but the general 
pattern of a 25%–40% reduction in accidents when two-lane roads are upgraded to four-lane 
dual carriageway standard is confirmed by data from Thailand. The reduction is particularly 
noticeable in the number of head-on collisions, which have the worst casualty rate and therefore 
the highest cost. Unit prices for valuing VOC, time, and accident costs were derived from a 
report on road user costs4 prepared for the DOH in early 2008 using 2006 prices. With minor 
adjustment, the report remains valid today. The exception is fuel prices, which have nearly

planning  and  implementing  all  aspects  of  resettlement.  The  DOH  sub-district  offices,  with 
assistance from technical assistance consultants, spearheaded the updating of the resettlement 
plan. The sub-district offices will continue this lead role during resettlement plan implementation. 
An RCC, composed of representatives from the DOH sub-district offices, the local government 
(district or municipality), and the affected households (most of whom are stall and/or shelter 
owners)  was  set  up  to  facilitate  systematic  relocation  of  stalls  and  shelters  and  houses, 
including the harvesting of annual crops and perennial trees. The RCC will serve as the main 
vehicle through which the affected households can actively participate in looking for a place 
outside of the ROW for them to continue operating their roadside livelihoods. The RCC will also 
help ensure that affected households are updated on the project, and that they are informed 
about the start of civil works in a specific section at least 3 months in advance. The project 
supervision consultants and the civil works contractors will also be represented in the RCC after 
they have been selected and mobilized. The project supervision consultants will continue to 
assist the PMO and the DOH sub-district offices during the implementation of the resettlement 
plan to ensure that social safeguard measures laid out in the resettlement plan are complied 
with. These consultants will provide needed training and capacity building inputs on a full-time 
basis. For this purpose, the consultants will have its own social development and  resettlement 
team,  composed  of  one  international  social  development  and  resettlement  specialist,  one 
domestic resettlement specialist, and one domestic gender specialist working an intermittently. 
13.  The  DOH,  through  its  PMO,  will  be  overall  responsible  for  internal  monitoring  of 
resettlement activities. Related reports will be submitted to ADB quarterly and uploaded onto the 
DOH's website and the ADB website. 
14.  The  cost  for  in-kind  assistance  and  restoration  measures  for  the  two  highways  is 
estimated at B34,157,210. This amount includes the costs of (i) dismantling and transferring 
affected stalls and shelters and houses, (ii) transporting totally affected stalls and shelters and 
houses to their new sites, (iii), preparing new sites for the stalls and shelters, (iv) operational 
and administrative expenses, and (v) contingencies. All assistance will be in-kind, and no cash 
assistance  will  be  provided  to  the  affected  households.  The  DOH  will  ensure  the  timely 
availability  of  funds  for  resettlement,  including  unforeseen  costs  in  excess  of  resettlement 
budget estimates to satisfy the project resettlement objectives.
